ratings.question_text: The readings/cases/textbooks used in this course were __________ .
Out-of-class assignments for this course were ___________ to my learning.
The workload for this course in comparison to other courses was ___________.
The pace of this class was ____________ for optimal learning.
Overall, the teaching assistant for this course was accessible, organized, and able to explain concepts clearly and thoroughly.
Field trips were well designed and ran smoothly.
I learned a lot from field trips.
How clearly does the instructor provide explanations of conceptual material?
How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: Please identify the teaching assistant with whom you interacted most closely _____________________ .
comments: Instructor: Timothy Michael Terway  Tim Terway
Instructor: Timothy Michael Terway  Timothy Terway
Instructor: Timothy Michael Terway  Tim
Instructor: Timothy Michael Terway  Yes
Instructor: Timothy Michael Terway  Tim was awesome especially given that he was finishing his phd.
Instructor: Timothy Michael Terway  Tim Terway
Instructor: Timothy Michael Terway  Tim

narratives.question_text: What were the strengths and weaknesses of your teaching assistant
comments: Instructor: Timothy Michael Terway  Tim had a clear mastery of the topic matter and was very good at explaining very challenging concepts.
Instructor: Timothy Michael Terway  Tim truly carries the class! Without him, it would have been really challenging.

Instructor: Timothy Michael Terway  Tim was a great asset to the course, but was also really busy with his dissertation and post-PHD plans. When he was present and focused he was amazing, but it was evident to the class that his head was elsewhere much of the semester. That said, I very much appreciated his contributions when he was engaged.
Instructor: Timothy Michael Terway  I think Tim is very helpful in class discussion and contents.

Instructor: Timothy Michael Terway  This course had the feeling of a course team-taught by two professors rather than one with a professor and a TA taking a backseat. Tim is phenomenal; no improvements necessary.
Instructor: Timothy Michael Terway  He brought things back down to our level and was very friendly, approachable and accessible.

Instructor: Timothy Michael Terway  Tim really carried this class. Susan is a great professor, but she can be pretty hard to follow sometimes. Tim was organized and really helped breakdown the more complicated aspects of the course for us. Without Tim to guide the class, I'm not sure I would have gotten much out of it! Thanks Tim! Towards the end of the class, Tim and Susan became a little less accessible and clear in their expectations. Tim was finishing his dissertation, which I know is a huge responsibility, but it did make for a few frustrating moments as we tried to finish our projects.

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-14, if you wish
comments: This class has a huge amount of potential but the class, the assignments, and the lectures need to be more structured to provide a more rigorous pathway to learning and mastering the material.
yes

I learned almost nothing from this course. I was very confused the entire semester and did not ever understand the direction in which it was going. I have no idea what Susan was saying half the time and never nothing was ever linked to anything else. The readings could have been helpful but they were so dense and theoretical that I did not understand them. If we would have discussed the readings in class and gone over what we were supposed to take from them, then maybe I would have understood more but the instructors just spoke to us as if we were now experts on the readings they assigned and never explained them so I was just lost the entire semester.

On Susan and Tim: Susan and Tim were a good teaching team. It's obvious Susan has done a lot of pioneering work in her field, but sometimes her theories were so complicated that having Tim there was really the difference between comprehension and having no idea what was going on. On the field trip: The Jackson, Wyoming field trip over spring break was the most valuable part of the course for me. I had a fantastic time meeting a bunch of different people from organizations I'm interested in, as well as exploring a part of the country I really like. It was a good bonding opportunity with my classmates as well. The field trip allowed us to put some of what we learned into practice, which was immensely helpful. On the course: I have such mixed feelings about this course. I wanted to love it, because I'm very interested in large-scale conservation. There are parts I did enjoy - my classmates, the field trip, my group project group. I also did learn some interesting things. However, the class was also pretty challenging - see my responses below for more details.

narratives.question_text: What were the best aspects of this course?
comments: The space it provided to think critically and ask challenging questions about the environmental field.
The field trip to Jackson and the very open, honest discussions in class.

The approach reviewed in this course transformed how I think about work being done in the conservation field as well as the work I hope to do in future. I am confident I will use this approach in future, and that my thinking will be better for this class. The group project component was also great. I appreciated the opportunity to dig deeply into an area of interest with my peers, and learned from all of the groups' presentations at the end of the semester.
The field trip to the Jackson Hole

This course challenged the way that I view conservation work. While it's at times really confusing - I'm pretty sure every student had no idea what was going on for at least a few weeks of the course - this course provides a framework for looking at large-scale problems (conservation or otherwise) that I think will be very beneficial to me moving forward.

The field trip! It made the course for me. Susan and Tim are also great people - they obviously cared about us as students and people and wanted us to get the most out of the course that we could. I also had a great group of classmates.

narratives.question_text: What aspects of this course need the most improvement?
comments: The structure.

Outlining of expectations and deliverables timeline from from the beginning. Sometimes it felt like assignments were dumped on us with very little notice and that was hard to accommodate due to other grad school meetings/assignments.

While the content was fantastic and transformative, the actual management of the class left much to be desired. Much of the semester felt scattered, and some of the individual classes lacked coherence/were repetitive of other classes. We were supposed to receive a weekly email about what the next week would hold since there was no syllabus, but this only materialized some weeks. Other logistical things also just failed to happen in a timely manner. While all of this was relatively frustrating during the semester, I increasingly see the big-picture benefits of the course now that I no longer have to deal with the logistical difficulties.
The reflections of the assignments
Sometimes Susan's explanations are too meta to follow.

Making sure that we review the readings since they are basically what they are trying to teach us. Also, making sure to connect what they talk about to other things and tell us where they are going ahead of time. I just did not understand the point of anything... or how it was relevant or connected to other things. The whole course was too abstract and theoretical.

I didn't take Susan's foundations course in the fall, where she explains in much more detail her work on the Policy Process (the foundation for this course and all her courses). As a result, I was lost for much of the semester, trying to make sense of what she was taking about. I expected the course to be about large-scale conservation efforts, and while there was that aspect to it, it was much more about how to reframe problems and goals to more effectively come up with solutions. That is a great skillset to have - but the course was taught in such a way that it could be extremely hard to follow at times. I wasn't sure what I was supposed to be learning. Susan and Tim warned us in the beginning that we would feel this way and that things would come together in the end, but it didn't make it easier.

narratives.question_text: Was the relationship between the course lectures and discussion/lab section
comments: Great

narratives.question_text: Discuss, if you wish, how this course fits into your overall program.  (Please feel free to describe how the course relates to your academic background.)
comments: I needed to question the technical skills I was learning and wanted a philosophical, ethical, and political lens to do so. Very few other classes offer this.
This is one of those game-changer courses. It has changed my whole conservation philosophy and trajectories. It has pieced together all of the questions and disconnects I've felt for a long time.

The learnings from this course are transferable to any topic (conservation and beyond). This course helped ground how I think about addressing challenges, defining problems, building consensus, and implementing work. I see this course as a theoretical frame for everything I will do at FES and in years to come.
Learned about the systematic thinking method
I'm interested in environmental law and policy, and this course is fundamentally about policy.
As I am very interested in large-scale conservation, this was an important class for me to take.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: I needed to question the technical skills I was learning and wanted a philosophical, ethical, and political lens to do so. Very few other classes offer this.

The course description is a little misleading in that it appears the course has a topical focus. While it technically does, this course is much more about understanding how to define and tackle problems at the conceptual level. I was expecting to "learn about large-scale conservation"...instead I learned about how to approach problems and solutions.
Was recommended by classmate and was curious about the course contents
This course got really good reviews, and I'd heard good things about Susan & Tim from people who took Susan's class in the fall.
I'm interested in conservation and learning about large-scale work seems really important
Like with Strategies for Land Conservation, this is one of the few classes at FES expressly for conservation studies. As that is the field I hope to go into after graduation, I had to take it.

narratives.question_text: Did the knowledge/skills that you gained from the course meet your expectations ?
comments: Mostly, but I would have benefited from more rigor and hands on learning.
Exceeded, far exceeded!

It turned out my expectations were off base (see above), but I am satisfied with what I got out of the class none the less. The tools and frameworks Susan teaches are powerful and will help me in the future.
Yes
Exceeded expectations.
Not at all. I learned very little from this course.

Yes and no. I'm still a little confused about what I should have walked away with, and I still harbor some general frustrations about the course. However, overall I did enjoy it, thought the field trip was very good, and I have done more self-reflection as a result of this course than any other. The course was a great opportunity for me to ask myself what I am interested in and why, how I can better diagnose and solve problems, and how I can better work with people with diverse interests.

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: We learned and taught each other a lot; learning would have been substantially reduced without it.

The group work was a great addition to this class. I liked that we were with the same group the entire semester and had the opportunity to dig in deeply to a broad topic and shape it ourselves. I learned a lot from my group, which was made up of folks from a variety of backgrounds.
Very great experience and I learned a lot

I normally loathe mandatory group work. I don't know if it was the subject matter, the assigned project, or the wonderful people in my group, but I found that group work in this course was enjoyable and really helpful to my learning experience in the class as a whole.
It was nice to have some people explain what they understood since most people were pretty lost.

We had a semester long group project, and I had a great group for mine. No complaints about the project aspect of the course. I think, in addition to the field trip, the group project was the most valuable aspect of the class. It allowed us to put into practice what we were learning and talk through some of the more challenging aspects of the course together.

narratives.question_text: For students who might consider taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: The ideas are essential to any environmental practitioner, but you're forced to do a lot of the heavy lifting if you want to get anything substantial out of it.
This course is about the existential philosophy of conservation. It is about the social process of conservation, not the biological or technical.

You will enjoy this class if you are able to think outside the box and are okay with working on projects/papers/assignments without much guidance. If you are the type of student who likes to understand what is going on at all times, this may not be the course for you. Much of the learning is self-driven.

Make peace with the logistical frustrations and 'hit and miss' classes early on in the semester so that you still benefit. Also accept that there will be ambiguity throughout. If you don't accept these things early on you risk preventing yourself from learning what you can (which is a lot!).
Generally is pretty good. People need to take this class.
Take this class! Go on the optional spring break trip to Jackson, too, if you can.

If you are a very philosophical thinker and like to ponder why things are what they are and dig really deeply into abstract thoughts, you may like this course. There were definitely some people who took a lot from it. If you are not, like me, you are probably going to be very lost and won't take much from it.

Go into the course understanding that it is going to be confusing and frustrating, but that you will learn and things will come together in the end (more or less). And go on the field trip to Jackson!
